title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text: This presentation analyzes seismic activity at Mount Vesuvius using the Tidy Tuesday dataset (May 13, 2025), exploring how frequency and depth have changed over time through scatter plots, histograms, and error plots, and how depth relates to magnitude with scatter plots, histograms, and animations. For the first question, the analysis reveals stabilized average depth and duration magnitude with increased frequency since 2016, while the second question shows frequent shallow events with varied magnitudes and less frequent, potentially more powerful deeper events, enhanced by elevation contours. The study employs well-documented R code and clear visualizations, though challenges with data resolution and animation consistency suggest areas for future improvement.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text: This presentation analyzes seismic activity at Mount Vesuvius using the Tidy Tuesday dataset (May 13, 2025), exploring how frequency and depth have changed over time through scatter plots, histograms, and error plots, and how depth relates to magnitude with scatter plots, histograms, and animations. For the first question, the analysis reveals stabilized average depth and duration magnitude with increased frequency since 2016, while the second question shows frequent shallow events with varied magnitudes and less frequent, potentially more powerful deeper events, enhanced by elevation contours. The study employs well-documented R code and clear visualizations, though challenges with data resolution and animation consistency suggest areas for future improvement.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Introduction
Exploratory analysis was conducted of seismic activity at Mount Vesuvius, Italy, utilizing the Mount Vesuvius Dataset from Tidy Tuesday (May 13, 2025). The dataset, spanning the last two decades, includes key variables such as latitude, longitude, depth_km, and duration_magnitude_md, which record the geographic coordinates, depth, and magnitude of seismic events. The project aims to uncover underlying relationships between these variables through time series and static analyses, addressing two primary research questions: (1) How have the frequency and depth of seismic events at Mount Vesuvius changed over time? and (2) How does the depth of seismic events relate to their magnitude, and are deeper events more powerful?

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Analysis

Question 1: How have the frequency and depth of seismic events at Mount Vesuvius changed over time?
See Tab: Question 1
The analysis examines temporal changes in the frequency and depth of seismic events by first wrangling the time column of the Mount Vesuvius Dataset to convert it into a usable date format, replacing “T” with a space and removing “Z”, then extracting year and month for aggregation. Data is filtered to remove missing duration_magnitude_md and depth_km values, and aggregated by year and month to calculate mean values, enabling a more fluid trend analysis. This approach employs a variety of visualizations (quite numerous) including scatter plots with geom_jitter and geom_smooth, histograms with geom_histogram, and error plots with geom_linerange and geom_errorbar—to assess frequency and depth changes over time. This multi-method strategy is supported by tidyverse and ggplot2 aiding in learning both overall and detailed distribution-level trends across the two-decade dataset.
The code is well-structured and has a good work-flow. Data wrangling with mutate and str_replace_all transforms the time column into a POSIXct date, while group_by and summarise aggregate the means by year and month. Visualization code, such as geom_jitter with geom_smooth and faceted geom_histogram, is clearly formatted with labeled axes and titles.
The visualizations are appropriate and clearly labeled. Scatter plots (plot_1, plot_2) show mean duration_magnitude_md and mean_depth_km by year with geom_jitter and a LOESS geom_smooth, using custom axes. Monthly plots (plot_3, plot_4) extend this to year-month with scale_x_date. Histograms (plot_5, plot_6) facet depth_km and duration_magnitude_md by year. Error plots (plot_9, plot_10) use geom_linerange and geom_errorbar to display ranges for tracking the temporal changes.
The analysis reveals that average depth and duration magnitude have stabilized over time, with a noticeable increase in event frequency since 2013, as indicated by histogram facets showing consistent depth distributions and low magnitude values (typically below 3). The LOESS smooths suggest a leveling off of trends, while error plots highlight variability, with deeper events becoming less frequent but still present. The rise in recorded events since 2016 aligns with improved data collection standard. This project aimed to analyze the data at a high level looking into the years overall, merging the more granular monthly data into an aggregate statistic.


Question 2: How does the depth of seismic events relate to their magnitude? Are deeper events more powerful?
See Tab: Question 2
The analysis investigates the relationship between seismic event depth and magnitude by cleaning the dataset to remove missing values in latitude, longitude, depth_km, and duration_magnitude_md. A new variable, depth_boundary_0.5km, is created to bin depths into 0.5 km intervals, with an additional depth_boundary_1km for broader categorization, enabling detailed spatial and statistical exploration. Point sizes are rescaled using rescale to reflect depth variations, and visualizations are developed in stages: an initial scatter plot maps magnitude and depth, a histogram facets magnitude by depth bins, a static plot adds elevation contours, and an animated plot transitions through depth layers using gganimate. This approach,uses a variety of methods to discoverer trends in a spatial context.
The code is well-organized and legible (though it could use commentary), utilizing dplyr for data manipulations including drop_na, mutate, filter, arrange. The case_when function creates depth bins with precise level definitions, and rescale adjusts point sizes and magnitudes. Elevation data is fetched with elevatr and processed into a dataframe, while gganimate configures transitions for the animated plot.
The visualizations are appropriate and labeled consistently. The initial scatter plot uses a Viridis “magma” color scale for duration_magnitude_md and alpha transparency for depth_abs, with axes limited to [14.34, 14.48] longitude and [40.78, 40.88] latitude. The histogram employs red fill and white outlines, faceted by depth_boundary_0.5km. The static plot integrates metR::geom_contour_fill with a gray-scale elevation discrete gradient color-bar and points sized by depth_rescaled, while the animated plot transitions through depth bins, using additional shadow effects. Legends are horizontally placed in all figures with titles and captions, adding consistency.
Diving into question 2 and the associated visualizations reveals that seismic activity is frequent at shallower depths (< 1 km), with varied magnitudes, while deeper events (> 5 km) are less frequent but exhibit higher average magnitudes, suggesting deeper events may be more powerful on average. The histogram confirms a skewed distribution toward lower magnitudes across all depths, and the static plot, visually improved by elevation contours, indicates a 1.2 km elevation gain toward the center, embedding depth relative to sea level. However, challenges with gganimate include theme preservation and contour accuracy highlight limitations.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Conclusion
This project effectively combines thoughtful data wrangling, well-planned visualizations, and insightful discussions to explore seismic activity at Mount Vesuvius, offering a foundation for future research into volcanic behavior.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
vesuvius <- read_csv("./data/vesuvius.csv")
glimpse(vesuvius)

Rows: 12,027
Columns: 11
$ event_id              <dbl> 4251, 4252, 22547, 22546, 22545, 22544, 22543, 2…
$ time                  <dttm> 2011-04-20 00:27:24, 2012-06-19 21:29:48, 2013-…
$ latitude              <dbl> 40.81800, 40.80883, 40.82217, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ longitude             <dbl> 14.43000, 14.42717, 14.42800, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ depth_km              <dbl> 0.42, 1.31, 0.06, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ duration_magnitude_md <dbl> 1.2, 0.7, 2.2, 0.2, 0.2, 0.0, 0.8, 1.4, -0.2, 0.…
$ md_error              <dbl> 0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.3…
$ area                  <chr> "Mount Vesuvius", "Mount Vesuvius", "Mount Vesuv…
$ type                  <chr> "earthquake", "earthquake", "earthquake", "earth…
$ review_level          <chr> "revised", "revised", "preliminary", "preliminar…
$ year                  <dbl> 2011, 2012, 2013, 2013, 2013, 2013, 2013, 2013, …


The Mount Vesuvius seismic activity dataset contains detailed information on 12,027 seismic events recorded between 2011 and 2024. Provided by the Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia and made available through the TidyTuesday project (May 13, 2025), the dataset captures both the temporal and spatial aspects of each event. Each record includes the event’s timestamp, latitude and longitude, depth in kilometers, magnitude based on duration (duration_magnitude_md), and an associated error estimate. Additional fields identify the type of event (such as “earthquake”), the review level of the data (e.g., “revised” or “preliminary”), and the year in which the event occurred. All events are local to the Mount Vesuvius region.
This dataset was selected because volcanoes are exciting! Mount Vesuvius is a historical icon and this dataset allows for real-world analysis of ongoing volcanic activity. It also offers both temporal and spacial components for visualizations and exploratory data analysis.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Questions

How have the frequency and depth of seismic events at Mount Vesuvius changed over time?
How does the depth of seismic events relate to their magnitude? Are deeper events more powerful?

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Analysis plan

A plan for answering each of the questions including the variables involved, variables to be created (if any), external data to be merged in (if any).

In our analysis, we will review the ideal way to represent the seismic events over time. There are multiple ways to represent the data, we will choose the most effective illustration to show the behavior of the seismic events. These are the basic type of plots that we will create:

Line plots in the time domain

This kind of plot are best to show trends over time

Histogram

This plot will be used to view if there are more activities at certain time of the year

Box plots

This can be used to view the deviation of the seismic event within a month or within the year

Joint plots

This can be used to observe any specific trends

Pair plots

On the other hand, the second question can be answered by reviewing the seismic events as follow:

Scatter plot of lat & lon

Including the geographical features
Vary the size of the markers based on the magnitude

Plot the data in 3D

Our data is in lat, lon, depth and magnitude

Animate the plot to show patterns not seen by all data at once

title: About
text:
This project was developed by Seismic Minds for INFO 526 - Data Analysis and Visualization at the University of Arizona, taught by Dr. Greg Chism. The team is comprised of the following team members.

Cedric Destin: I am an Electrical Engineer major, I specialized in communication and Signal Processing. 2025 will be my last year of graduate school.
Weston Scott: I am an Algorithms and Signal Processing Engineer in my second to last semester for my Master’s in Electrical and Computer Engineering program.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
The Data




Mount Vesuvius Dataset from Tidy Tuesday (May 13, 2025)
The data contains records of seismic activity at or near Mt. Vesuvius, Italy over the last 2 decades
The goal is to interpret the underlying relationships between variables of interest including time series and static analyses of the seismic data recorded at the famous Mt. Vesuvius.
TidyTuesday Source

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Exploratory Question 1

How have the frequency and depth of seismic events at Mount Vesuvius changed over time?

This section of the presentation reviews the behaviors of the seismic events’ over time
The following plots are used to analyze the duration_magnitude_md and the depth_md of the seismic events

Line plots
Histograms
Error plots

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Approach



Any NaN were removed from the depth_md and duration_magnitude_md data

vesuvius_data_filtered <- vesuvius_data |> 
    filter(!is.na(duration_magnitude_md) & !is.na(depth_km))



The data was down-sampled by calculating the averages per month and year.

aggregated_data <- vesuvius_data_filtered |>   
    group_by(year) |>   
    summarise(mean_duration_magnitude_md = mean(duration_magnitude_md),             
    mean_depth_km = mean(depth_km))



The time had to be wrangled to remove undesired characters

vesuvius_data <- vesuvius_data |>     mutate(         
    date = str_replace_all(time, "T", " "),         
    date = str_replace_all(date, "Z", ""),         
    date = as.POSIXct(date, format = "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"))

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Plots

TimeplotsDepth StatsDuration Magnitude Stats







Time plot of the duration_magnitude and dept_km for seismic event down-sampled.




Note: This shows that the average depth_md and duration_magnitude_md measured have lowered within the years.










This plot shows the “trend” of depth_md, the spread of the depth_md and breaks down the frequency of the depth_md for each year.




Note: Another view of the Depth of the seismic events over time. This view shows the frequency of the depth_md for each year.










This plot shows the “trend” of the duration_magnitude_md, the spread of the duration_magnitude_md and breaks down the frequency of the duration_magnitude by year.




Note: Another view of the Duration Magnitude of the seismic events over time.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Analysis


The Depth and the Duration Magnitude of the seismic events are became smaller
More Events have been recorded since 2016
The Duration Magnitude remains low (below 3)

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Challenges Faced


How to interpret and down-sample the data.

Since the data has such a high variation it was not evident to notice a pattern unless the data was down-sampled.

Choosing the plots that best illustrate behavior of the data.

After down-sampling the data, it was challenging to decide on what type of plot would illustrate the behavior of the data.

Creating bins and counting the frequency if the events
Overlaying the mountain over the depth_md seismic events, the latitude and longitude needed to be translated to time to add within the plots of depth_md

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Exploratory Question 2

How does the depth of seismic events relate to their magnitude? Are deeper events more powerful?

Exploring this question requires extraction of hidden data to synthesize new variable, aiding in exploring the seismic activity at Mt. Vesuvius
Extracting data into effective visualizations involved utilizing ggplot, geom_point, geom_contour_fill, geom_hist, and integrating with gganimate
These visuals provide a viewing window into the trends connecting seismic event magnitudes with depth

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Approach



The first step was to remove bad (or missing) data by dropping rows with NA in latitude, longitude, depth_km, and duration_magnitude_md

vesuvius_data_filtered <- vesuvius_data |>
    drop_na(
        latitude, 
        longitude, 
        depth_km, 
        duration_magnitude_md
    )



The first step was to down-sample the raw depth data into levels only depth boundaries spanning 0.5 km bands, creating a new variable titled depth_boundary_0.5km, plotting in ascending depth order meaning that deeper values will appear first

vesuvius_data <- read.csv(here("data","vesuvius.csv"))
vesuvius_data_filtered <- vesuvius_data_filtered |>
    mutate(
        depth_abs = abs(depth_km),
        depth_boundary_1km = case_when(
            depth_km < 1 ~ "< 1 km",
            depth_km < 2 ~ "< 2 km",
            depth_km < 3 ~ "< 3 km",
            depth_km < 4 ~ "< 4 km",
            depth_km < 5 ~ "< 5 km",
            TRUE ~ "> 5 km"),
        
        depth_boundary_1km = factor(
            depth_boundary_1km, 
            levels = c("< 1 km", 
                      "< 2 km", 
                      "< 3 km", 
                      "< 4 km", 
                      "< 5 km", 
                      "> 5 km")),
        
        depth_boundary_0.5km = case_when(
            depth_km < 0.5 ~ "< 0.5 km",
            depth_km < 1 ~ "0.5 ~ 1 km",
            depth_km < 1.5 ~ "1 ~ 1.5 km",
            depth_km < 2 ~ "1.5 ~ 2 km",
            depth_km < 2.5 ~ "2 ~ 2.5 km",
            depth_km < 3 ~ "2.5 ~ 3 km",
            depth_km < 3.5 ~ "3 ~ 3.5 km",
            depth_km < 4 ~ "3.5 ~ 4 km",
            depth_km < 4.5 ~ "4 ~ 4.5 km",
            depth_km < 5 ~ "4.5 ~ 5 km",
            TRUE ~ "> 5 km"),
        
        depth_boundary_0.5km = factor(
            depth_boundary_0.5km, 
            levels = rev(c("< 0.5 km", 
                      "0.5 ~ 1 km", 
                      "1 ~ 1.5 km", 
                      "1.5 ~ 2 km", 
                      "2 ~ 2.5 km", 
                      "2.5 ~ 3 km",
                      "3 ~ 3.5 km", 
                      "3.5 ~ 4 km", 
                      "4 ~ 4.5 km", 
                      "4.5 ~ 5 km", 
                      "> 5 km")))
    ) |>

    filter(
        !is.na(depth_boundary_0.5km)
    ) |>

    arrange(
        depth_boundary_0.5km, 
        desc(depth_rescaled)
    ) |> glimpse()



A size re-scaling for points was created from this new depth layer variable

  vesuvius_data_filtered <- vesuvius_data_filtered |>
      mutate(
        depth_rescaled = rescale(depth_km, to = c(1, 11)),
        mag_rescaled = rescale(duration_magnitude_md, to = c(0.4, 0.9))
    )



Initially a visualization was created to simply view lat/long axes with points that were colored by the duration_magnitude_md and a transparency difference based on depth_km (see Initial View on next slide)

original <-
    ggplot(
        vesuvius_data_filtered, 
        aes(x = longitude, 
            y = latitude)
    ) +
    
    geom_point(
        aes(color = duration_magnitude_md,
            alpha = depth_abs),
        size = 3
    ) +                     
    
    scale_color_viridis_c(
        option = "inferno",
        name = "Magnitude"
    ) +
    
    scale_alpha_continuous(
        name = "Depth (km)",
        range = c(0.75, 0.25)
    ) +

        scale_x_continuous(
            limits = c(14.34, 14.48), 
            expand = c(0, 0)
        ) +
        scale_y_continuous(
            limits = c(40.78, 40.88), 
            expand = c(0, 0)
        ) + 
        ...



Next the data was plotted as histograms of the duration_magnitude_md, but faceted by the newer depth_boundary_0.5km variable, showing the groupings of points clearer, as well as their distributions across the magnitude scale

histogram <- 
    ggplot(
        vesuvius_data_filtered, 
        aes(x = duration_magnitude_md)
    ) +

    geom_histogram(
        binwidth = 0.2, 
        fill = 'red', 
        color = "white"
    ) +

    facet_wrap(
        ~ depth_boundary_0.5km, 
        scales = "free_y"
    ) +
    ...



After learning from the histogram, the initial plot was updated to plot the points with varying sizes based on depth_boundary_0.5km, with contour lines of the elevation in the same region, an accompanying animated plot followed it

static_plot <- ggplot() +
    metR::geom_contour_fill(
        data = elev_df,
        aes(x = x, 
            y = y,
            z = elevation/1000, 
            group = NULL),
        bins = 10
    ) +

    scale_fill_gradientn(
        colors = gray.colors(10, start = 1.0, end = 0.3),
        name = "Elevation (km)",
        limits = c(-0.111, 1.246),  # Match elevation range from elev_df (km)
        breaks = seq(0, 1.2, by = 0.3)
    ) +

    geom_point(
        data = vesuvius_data_filtered,
        aes(x = longitude, 
            y = latitude,
            color = duration_magnitude_md,
            size = depth_rescaled),
        alpha = 0.75
    ) +
    ...

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Seismic Activity Plots

Initial ViewHistogram ViewStatic ViewAnimated View







First pass at plotting depth and mangitude on lat/lon




Note: This plot shows initial conditions of seismic events around Mount Vesuvius, with the color representing the magnitude and transparency reflecting depth (use this as a baseline for comparison)










Binned the depth variable into discreted bins of 0.5 km




Note: Histogram of duration_magnitude_md, faceted by depth_boundary_0.5km, confirming confirms distribution shapes and valid bins for all layers










Upgraded initial plot to adjust sizing of points based on depth bin




Note: With the addition of the elevation contours and the the sizing of points based on depth, it is clearer where the points are localized and the depths associated (relative to sea level)










Animation of the finalized static plot, highlighting each depth bin in a loop




Note: The animation highlights each depth bin (0.5 km region) starting from the deepest points, highlighting the localized groups of points in each layer

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Analysis


Seismic activity occurs quite frequently, and looking at the histogram alone, it is clear that more events occur at the shallower depths
Though there are data points that suggest powerful magnitude events can occur at shallow depths, the static plot, animated plot, and histogram agree that more powerful events occur at deeper depths on average, but are much less frequent as compared to the activity closer to the surface
It should be noted that with the elevation contour lines that the deeper events are truly much deeper than the points localized in the center of Mt. Vesuvius. There is about a 1.2 km elevation gain from the outer region of the landmark compared to the center.

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Challenges Faced


Manipulating the depth_km field was challenging due to the amount of data in each bin. It was essential that at least one data point was in each division, but showing the fewer bins than what was used proved to not be effective in showing the trends
gganimate does not preserve all the theme options that were established and called out, leading to a plot that closely resembles it’s static counterpart, but not equivalent in the features desired. Contour lines seemed to not work right, now drawing the layers as intended.
Formatting legends also proved to be a labor of love, as there are many ways to show them, but keeping consistency among the plots created a rigorous amount of testing with many options added to ensure they appeared ‘uniform’

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
Final Remarks

TODO

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
The following libraries / functions will be used in order to answer Question 1, “How have the frequency and depth of seismic events at Mount Vesuvius changed over time?”

geom_point:

-   Creating a scatter plot of the seismic events (depth and duration-magnitude) over time

geom_line:

Creating a scatter plot of the seismic events (depth and duration-magnitude) over time

geom_bar:

View the frequency of the seismic events aggregated per year or year, month




Rows: 12,027
Columns: 12
$ event_id              <int> 4251, 4252, 22547, 22546, 22545, …

title: Mt. Vesuvius Lives
text:
The following libraries / functions will be used in order to answer Question 1, “How have the frequency and depth of seismic events at Mount Vesuvius changed over time?”

geom_point:

-   Creating a scatter plot of the seismic events (depth and duration-magnitude) over time

geom_line:

Creating a scatter plot of the seismic events (depth and duration-magnitude) over time

geom_bar:

View the frequency of the seismic events aggregated per year or year, month
